results.title: As the mirror burns
results.creator_credit: Cristina Pozzan, Diane Bretherton and Musical Films
results.brief_description: In this illuminating documentary, Melbourne psychologist and peace activist, Dr. Di Bretherton, reveals the untold story of the women in the Vietnam War. Few people are aware that women made up a large proportion of the Vietnamese forces. As she travels through the Vietnam of the 90’s, Di Bretherton introduces us to the women who fought for their country, living with their families in complex tunnel systems, as their country was bombed and defoliated. The film also covers the long-term effects of the war caused by chemicals such as Agent Orange.

results.title: As good as it gets
results.creator_credit: James L. Brooks, Bridget Johnson, Kristi Zea and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Melvin (Jack Nicholson) has established a regimented lifestyle which enables him to cope with his obsessive-compulsive disorder. His routine existence is interrupted by changes in the lives of his neighbour Simon (Greg Kinnear), and his waitress Carol (Helen Hunt). Caring for Simon’s dog, and his involvement in Carol’s personal life puts him back in touch with a humanity which has been lacking in his structured life. Powerful performances from Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt, who both won Best Actor Oscars for their efforts.

results.title: Arthritis: a dialogue with pain
results.creator_credit: Susan Huycke, Robert Verrall, Roman Kroitor, William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film about arthritis, its effect upon people’s lives, the nature of the disease, and how it can be combated. Through the stories of people suffering from arthritis—young and old, mildly to severely afflicted—and interviews with medical professionals, this documentary provides answers to widely asked questions. It is also about pain and the will to conquer pain.

results.title: Asian adventure
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger, Australian Television Network and Grainger Maynard
results.brief_description: This visually stunning documentary captures the most forbidding and exotic of Asian locations in a series of fast moving adventures. Journey through China on a month-long bicycle tour through the southern Province of Guandong, witness dragon-boat racing and the magic of Chinese National Day celebrations. In India visit the magnificent waterways and colourful houseboats of Kashmir, tour the ancient fort city of Jhodpur and travel by camel across the Great Rajasthan Desert. Witness the magnificent spectacle of the city of Jaisalmer and embark on a fascinating bike ride from the famous pink city of Jaipur to Agra and it’s breathtaking temple of love, the Taj Mahal.

results.title: Asia Wise (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John Honey, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Education Dept Tasmania
results.brief_description: A compilation of some of the most important and informative reports from the ABC TV program Asia Wise during 1989. The stories address social, political and cultural issues. In the diverse and complex countries of Asia today it seems the only unifying forces are, paradoxically, change and tradition. Topics covered are: - Student protests in China; peasants in China; the new Cambodia; Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong; Japanese youth; the depletion of Asian forests; Japanese tea ceremony; Yum cha.

results.title: As tears go by
results.creator_credit: Wong, Rover Tang and In-gear Film
results.brief_description: Wong Kar-wai describes his first feature as ‘a tragedy set in the big city, focussing on several ordinary characters in a hopeless situation’. It has also been described as ‘an idiosyncratic riff on the plot and themes of Scorsese’s Mean Streets’. Ah Wah (Andy Lau) is an enigmatic hit man who, with his offsider Fly (Jacky Cheung), is, despite himself, dragged into trouble time and time again. The arrival of his cousin (Maggie Cheung) briefly offers hope of escape from the downward spiral. The emphasis is more on atmosphere and interplay between the three characters than upon plot. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Arthur Boyd: testament of a painter
results.creator_credit: Don Bennetts, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Don Bennetts Films and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: A biographical documentary on one of Australia’s most prolific artists, Arthur Boyd. A charming, gentle, compassionate man, Arthur Boyd was born in 1920 in Murrumbeena, Melbourne, into a family of artists - a family who was known for its eccentricities and stern religious background. In this film we see Arthur chatting with his two young grandsons, providing them with a historical glimpse into their family background through old photographs and stories which have been passed down through the generations, along with his own personal memories of growing up in such a dynasty of “painters, potters, and dreamers”. Boyd was a figurative artist whose work focused on the human condition within the Australian landscape and although he did spend many years out of Australia in London and Europe, his works always retained the Australian spirit. Through stills, home movies, interviews, personal narratives and examples of his paintings, this program endeavours to give an overview of Boyd’s evolving journey through the decades, from his early aspirations to being an actor to finally becoming a serious painter and sculptor. We also see Boyd at work in 1993 as he prepares for a retrospective Exhibition to be held at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. Arthur Boyd has left his legacy to the Australian people by bequeathing three of his properties as a gift to the nation, including the well-known “Bundanon” property which houses artists in residence, an education centre and several of Boyd’s paintings. Arthur Boyd died on 24 April 1999. This superb documentary is a testimony to a truly great artist. Narrated by Oliver Streeton.

results.title: Arthur Boyd: figures in a landscape
results.brief_description: A fascinating program that looks at the painting of Australian artist, Arthur Boyd. For the purposes of this peacefully but not passively photographed documentary, Arthur Boyd completed two different paintings of the same scene, an interior and an exterior interpretation of bathers and water skiers who regularly churn up the tranquillity outside his door, explaining as he works, his inspiration and intention.
